cleaned_comment: It's true that France has taken in a lot of people. This is also due to the fact that France has always had many colonies, and these people have always liked to visit their motherland, their homeland. So in Germany we didn't have this phenomenon, we had only a few small colonies that we already lost in the last century. So after the Second World War, which we lost - you all know, Germany was really about, Germany suffered, so I don't want to put us on a stall, not even talking about all the money we had to pay to foreign countries, but finally right away, Germany recovered already in the flashy years, We were able to live a first economic boom and we welcomed the first immigrants, it was mainly Italians in a first phase, then Spaniards, Portuguese, then Austrians, there were less certainly therefore from the flashy years, sixty in any case and they were welcome besides. Then, for a while, fewer people came, and then the Turks arrived en masse, but it was the Anatolian plateau that was recreated in Germany, and at that time, of course, the first Beurs, the first Hungarians, were born, and at that time we really had to begin to create this balance in society - we could compare it with the wave of Algerians who arrived in France, but well - we mustn't deviate too much from the subject, So we have to discuss among ourselves how we can welcome people in our country or how we can really ensure the existence of these people who arrive in our country in the short and medium term, or even until 2030, and then we have to distinguish once again between the legal and the illegal, as was said at the beginning. I would even go one step further and say that all those who want to come from Africa, for example, to our country now - for example Lampedusa, the Italian island which is almost overpopulated by Africans - how can we address these people? How can we tell them: we want to welcome you but not like this? These are not the right conditions. Now we don't have the possibilities.

Donc en Allemagne on n’a pas connu ce phénomène, on a eu que quelques petites colonies qu’on a déjà perdues au depuis du siècle. Donc après le deuxième guerre mondiale que nous avons perdus – vous le savez tous, l’Allemagne était vraiment about, l’Allemagne a souffert, donc je ne voudrais pas nous mettre sur un pied des stalles, même pas parler de tout l’argent que nous avons dû payer aux pays étrangers mais finalement tout de suite, l’Allemagne s’est récupéré déjà dans les années clinquantes, on a pu vivre un premier boom économique et on a accueilli les premiers immigrants, c’étaient surtout les Italiens dans une première phase, après des Espagnoles, des Portugais, ensuite les Autrichiens, on y avait moins certes donc à partir des années clinquantes, soixantes en tout cas et ils étaient les bienvenues d’ailleurs. Puis pendant tout un temps il y a eu moins qui sont venus et après ce sont les Turques qui sont arrivées de manière massive mais donc c’est le plateau de l’Anatolie en fait qui s’ait recrée en Allemagne et à ce moment-là, évidemment, ce sont les premiers Beurs, les premiers Hongrois qui sont né et à ce moment-là on a vraiment du commencer à créer cette équilibre dans la société à la limite – on la pourrait comparer avec la vague des Algériens qui sont arrivés en France mais bon – il ne faut non plus se dévier trop du sujet, donc il s’agit de discuter entre nous, comment pouvons-nous accueillir les gens chez nous ou comment pouvons-nous à court et à moyen terme ou même jusqu’au 2030 vraiment assurer l’existence de ces gens-là qui arrivent chez nous et puis il faut, une fois de plus, faire la distinction entre les légaux et les illégaux, comme cela était dit au début. Donc là également il faudrait voir quelles sont les solutions possibles afin que les gens ne soient pas justement des illégaux et j’irais même un pas plus loin en disant que tous ceux qui veulent venir par exemple de l’Afrique – chez nous maintenant – par exemple Lampedusa, l’île italienne qui est presque surpeuplé par les Africains – comment pouvons-nous nous adresser à ces gens-là ? cleaned_comment: Our geographical situation in our islands is obviously different from that of the peninsula, we have not experienced problems with legal immigrants, who have been established for many years and the foreigners in our country have accepted and respected our customs in a way in the religious schools, even if they do not follow religious activities, but in no way have they wanted or asked that we remove our religious symbols. People have their own celebrations apart. But the question that arises now is not the legal immigration, but obviously the clandestine. Those who arrive without being asked, without being necessary. I don't know what happened; there was a month and a half or two months without any makeshift boats arriving here, although the method is favourable. So I am very surprised. But now we are in a situation - I don't know if we don't want to, but I speak for them - where they arrive in such a lamentable state. We can't even help them, they go straight to the internment center. Why did they leave   their country of origin. Why are they poor there? Well, they left because they can't live. So, it's a difficult situation to find a solution there. In the Canary Islands, the question of immigration is really serious because there is illegal immigration; the immigrants manage to flow the controls and then, above, obviously, there is delinquency and all the consequences of delinquency. And if they were welcomed, if they had any opportunity it would be better. And, again, we come to the question of work and there is no work for these people. Yes, they have priority in the nurseries, in the schools, for social housing and there are young people who are on the list for an apartment to start a family and they don't succeed. But a foreigner, an immigrant, can't do anything easily. And therefore it will create ill-being. The solution which is right, I do not know. But that's why we're here, to find a solution.

cleaned_comment: I also wanted to say that I agree with Jürgen. In the 70's there was a dictatorship in Spain and at that time there was a lack of work, so a lot of people went to Germany. A friend of mine went there for example and culturally - or France, there were many Spaniards - and now he has a pension, he worked in Munich for a long time and he also worked at the streetcar in Munich and he lived his life there, he has his children there, he lives there and then he moved to Frankfurt sometime in between, but he integrated and at a time when he was asked. And he has cleaned plates in restaurants and done all kinds of things, but depending on the development of the economic situation and his adaptation, he has naturalized there and now it has been better for him to stay in Germany than to come back to Spain. Well, what Jürgen said about the politicians who don't dare to say things that the people think, or maybe even the majority thinks, we have to see how semantically that can be delivered; how can you work to make sure that there are things that are negative, or sound negative, without it immediately sounding like discrimination when that is mentioned? There you have to ask yourself if people would be interested in what people think, otherwise you just behave demagogically and then you don't represent the people. I think what Jürgen said; which is really very important to me, the politicians don't listen, don't want to know what the people want. We are not represented. There are so common opinions - I don't remember your name - but people come to us because they have to. They are in a state where they need that. If you live in Senegal and you are starving, you try to find a way out. And we have to understand that what we offer them is really something great. But now we don't offer anything to anyone. And then what do they get? Then they become beggars, or thieves, or something else. We just have to see what kind of people there are in the country, where they come from everywhere, and their children. Ein Freund von mir ging da hin zum Beispiel und kulturell gesehen – oder Frankreich, da gab es viele Spanier – und jetzt hat er eine Rente, er hat lange in München gearbeitet und er hat auch bei der Strassenbahn in München gearbeitet und der hat da sein Leben geführt, der hat da seine Kinder, er lebt da und ist dann nach Frankfurt gezogen irgendwann dazwischen, aber er hat sich integriert und das zu einer Zeit, wo er gefragt wurde. Und er hat Teller geputzt in Restaurants und alles mögliche getan, aber je nach Entwicklung der wirtschaftlicher Lage und seiner Anpassung, hat er sich da eingebürgert und jetzt ist es ihm lieber gewesen, in Deutschland zu bleiben als nach Spanien zurückzukommen. Nun, was Jürgen sagte zu den Politikern, die sich nicht trauen, Sachen zu sagen, die das Volk denkt, oder vielleicht sogar die Mehrheit denkt, da müssen wir sehen, wie semantisch das überbracht werden kann; wie kann man daran arbeiten, dass es Dinge gibt, die negativ sind, beziehungsweise klingen, ohne dass das sofort nach Diskriminierung klingt wenn das erwähnt wird? Es gibt so allgemein verbreitete Meinungen - ich weiss nicht mehr wie du heisst - aber die Leute kommen zu uns weil sie zu uns müssen. Sie befinden sich ja in einem Zustand wo sie das brauchen. Wenn du in Senegal lebst und da verhungerst, da versuchst du da einen Ausweg zu finden. Und wir müssen ja verstehen dass das, was wir denen anbieten, wirklich etwas Tolles ist. cleaned_comment: So I think we're dealing with two absolutely fundamental problems. cleaned_comment: JÜ:  We in Berlin, of course, have the problems of the stragglers with our Turkish workers, whom we have had for over 40 years now. It was said that in order to make it easier for people to immigrate to Germany, we want to relocate them, we want to place them among the Germans, so that they can grow up with the language, with the culture, so that we can adopt their culture. That is an enrichment for us in Germany, we have seen that in the past, where the emperor let the Huguenots come to Berlin, how our culture has grown and we should keep that. But I say, all immigrants who come legally or illegally, who come illegally, they don't come for nothing. That was already said by Ana correctly, somewhere it is missing in the countries and they do not come in illegally to us for nothing. So these all, how they want to come in the individual countries, should first be ready to learn language in the text and in the expression. Then they are certainly welcome in many countries. But as it is with us at present still in Berlin that they are not ready to learn the language, then they are also not welcome. Welcome are those who want to do something for the gross national product, who want to bring the country forward. And those who only want to rest on their bones, that's probably how everyone feels, namely only accept the social aspects and gratefully accept them, want to profit economically from them, probably every country doesn't need them like that. And that is already once a problem, which actually the politicians in completely Europe - and if we want to grow together still more closely and should, which would be naturally fantastically, there one must address these things also times with the politicians. You would have to actually listen to the people again, listen. Where is it stuck with us in the people, why are we not ready to accept every legal or illegal immigrant? Why? And they don't. cleaned_comment: In Spain, not everyone who comes into the country can actually get a job. In Spain we have a commission, a council, an advisory board, where then also members from the unions, from the companies, from the government are represented. And for each province in Spain, the employment needs on the labor market are then examined. And on the basis of these assessments, they then try to find workers. And then there is also a system of investment in the country of origin, especially if that is a country that is very close, so that is clear, if we don't help the countries outside the EU, then we can never solve the problem. So we really have to find a balance. Since this law was passed in Spain, a lot has changed. You saw that in the summer, when many immigrants came by boat or by plane, everything actually went quite well, because the employment needs, the needs of the labor market were taken into account. That more or less worked, but I think it has to be extended to the entire EU, so the needs of the labor market really have to be assessed and then there can be a common policy for the whole of Europe. Otherwise, you shoot each other in the foot and then no problems are solved at all. It is important, for example, that this cannot be left to the companies alone or only to the political parties, because if, for example, we have a political party that has a different opinion than the others, then there should be such a commission, such an advisory board, which consists of the different layers of the population, of the different parties concerned, and then the needs are evaluated. The trade unions, the governments, the companies should then participate. Because at the moment it is mostly the case that only the companies have a say. I think that everyone should have a say in this. Social agencies don't really have a say either. But it is very important that they participate. We really have to make sure that each country decides what its own needs are, and then there should be such an agency at the European Union level, in the European Parliament, so that the common needs can be assessed. And then it will be decided whether the guest workers, the immigrants will be allowed to come to the EU. On the other hand, we must then also help in the countries of origin. Everyone understands, of course, when there is such a problem. Then, of course, one's own interests are always represented. The political interests, the economic aspects are brought forward when there are problems. Of course I have my political ideas, I don't deny that either, but I don't really have a political option. I can only represent the workers, because we also have to earn our bread. So I can't just say, yes, that's the lesser evil.

Dabei gibt es dann auch ein System der Investition im Ursprungsland, vor allen Dingen wenn das ein Land ist, dass ganz in der Nähe ist, also das ist ja klar, wenn wir den Ländern ausserhalb der EU nicht helfen, dann können wir das Problem nie lösen. Sie haben das dann im Sommer gesehen, als viele Einwanderer mit den Schiffen gekommen sind oder mit den Flugzeugen, da ist dann auch alles eigentlich ganz gut verlaufen, denn die Beschäftigungsbedürfnisse, die Bedürfnisse des Arbeitsmarktes sind berücksichtigt worden. Das hat mehr oder weniger funktioniert, aber ich denke, dass muss auf die gesamte EU ausgeweitet werden, also da müssen wirklich die Bedürfnisse des Arbeitsmarktes bewertet werden und dann kann es dann eine gemeinsame Politik für ganz Europa geben. Anders schiesst man sich gegenseitig ins Bein und dann werden überhaupt keine Probleme gelöst. Es ist zum Beispiel wichtig, dass man das nicht allein den Unternehmen überlassen kann oder nur den politischen Parteien, denn wenn wir zum Beispiel eine politische Partei haben, die eine Meinung hat als die andere, also da soll es so eine Kommission, einen solchen Beirat geben, der aus den verschiedenen Schichten der Bevölkerung besteht, aus den verschiedenen betroffenen Parteien, und da werden dann die Bedürfnisse bewertet. Da sollen dann die Gewerkschaften sich beteiligen, die Regierungen, die Unternehmen. Denn augenblicklich ist es ja meistens so jetzt, dass nur die Unternehmen ein Wort zu sagen haben. Ich denke, dass also da wirklich jeder ein Wort beilegen soll. Auch Sozialagenturen haben nicht wirklich etwas zu sagen. Das ist aber sehr wichtig, dass sie sich da beteiligen. Wir müssen wirklich dafür sorgen, dass jedes Land beschliesst, welches die eigenen Bedürfnisse sind, und dann soll es dann auf Ebene der Europäischen Union, im europäischen Parlament eine solche Agentur auf europäischer Ebene geben, damit dann die gemeinsamen Bedürfnisse bewertet werden können. Und da wird dann entschieden, ob die Gastarbeiter, die Einwanderer in die EU kommen dürfen. Andererseits müssen wir dann auch in den Ursprungsländern helfen. Jeder versteht natürlich, wenn es ein solches Problem gibt. Dann werden natürlich immer die eigenen Interessen vertreten. Die politischen Interessen, die wirtschaftlichen Aspekte werden nach vorne gebracht, wenn es Probleme gibt. Ich hab natürlich auch meine politischen Ideen, das verneine ich auch nicht, aber ich hab nicht wirklich eine politische Option. Ich kann nur die Arbeiter vertreten, denn wir müssen ja auch unser Brot verdienen. Da kann ich dann nicht einfach sagen, ja das ist das kleinere Übel. [12:18]

On voit bien dans les trente, quarante derniers années, qu’il y a des gens qui sont venus, et qui on bossé sur des secteurs et je pense qu’on peut le dire, ils ont bossé sur les secteurs où chez nous, on n’a pas eu l’envie d’y aller. Mais je pense que quelqu’un qui a envie de s’intégrer, moi j’imagine que dans les pays européen, ce ne sont pas des styles de vies très très atypiques, et je pense si quelqu’un veut s’intégrer, en travaillant et en vivant entre di et mi[ ?] comme tous le monde et je pense que ça n’impose pas un énorme problème. cleaned_comment: During the break, I thought about what we were saying earlier and I think that already, between men and women, we don't have the same sense of sensitivity regarding immigration. If I look around this table, I have the impression that women in general, I am sorry for the gentlemen, are more tolerant and more open to a certain form of cultural mix and integration and men are more recalcitrant, we will say, to this opening. Having said that, I listened to what was said just now, and I asked myself two questions, which are fundamental questions; when we are dealing with the problem of immigration, first of all, what do the immigrants expect from us and what do we expect from them? So, there were some answers already, we expect them to be hard-working, to be courageous, to be honest, to be respectful, okay? And so that's what we expect from them. And what do they expect from us? Well, they can expect certain things. We're talking about legal immigration. They can wait to have a good job, they can wait to find themselves with that good job in a peaceful country, they can also wait, if they already have family, in the ten countries, to be able to find, join their family. Okay, they have all the right reasons to want to come here. But there are always counterparts and it is true that we cannot tolerate all of them and I think that we must put a B on this and say that immigration works well if it is controlled. If we don't do anything, because by wanting to integrate all these people, by wanting to get all the misery in the world, we create frustrated people in our countries, we create people who may be unemployed, they may think - rightly or wrongly - that it is the immigrant who has taken a potential job. As a result, there is a risk of tension, rivalry and animosity. Is immigration at all costs good, even for us? We really have to think about this. I say that welcoming people is very good, I am in favor of diversity, I am in favor of all these mixtures and integrations, but we must not let it be too much, because too much is necessarily to the detriment of one or the other party. It can be really even downright damaging, you have to be extremely careful.

cleaned_comment: I would like to say something to Sören. The main problem with all immigrants is the languages. And I see this again and again, there are families, Turks have four, five, six children. The mother stays at home and raises her children. The children don't learn a word of German until the age of six. Or hardly any German. Then they are supposed to start school and they fail in school. And thus the slippery slope is set. And this has been recognized much too late. In principle, the children have to play with the German children. And that is unfortunately not wanted by the Turks either. Also with the kindergartens. That is not enough, if for example in Berlin, there are areas, that are 50% Turks, 50% Germans. And then the Turks are together and the Germans are together and in kindergarten the Turks don't learn enough German either. That is the main obstacle to getting close to the people and even starting a discussion with them. But work is now being done on this in Germany. But this has only been the case for a year or two, and we hope that this will help us get a grip on the problem. As far as crime is concerned, this is a sociological problem. A well-educated Turk or Muslim is no more a criminal than a German. The crime rate is basically the same. Then I wanted to say something to Antonia about you. I work in China and in Arab countries. These are two worlds. The Chinese are much, much poorer, they really have nothing. The Arabs, on the other hand, still live in wealth. And I have Chinese women at home all the time, they are incredibly ambitious from the start. They go to the adult education center, learn German, and then go to the hospitals because I'm a doctor. I can mediate that. They stay there for a year, go back to China and pass on their knowledge there. With the Chinese, it is possible to have excellent cooperation. If you say you start work at 8, they are there at 8. I have never managed to say in a hospital in Yemen, I start at 8 o'clock. The boss comes at 11. And there are 30 patients sitting outside, and I treat them with a nurse. But when they ask the boss and say, "tomorrow we start at 8 o'clock, perhaps a quarter past eight," he doesn't come until 10 o'clock. He just doesn't feel like it at all. I have found that it is very difficult to make an appointment with them and then to follow through with organizations. The mentality of Muslims is completely different from that of the Chinese and Europeans. And they are not dumber, the Muslims or the Yemenis. They just have a completely different structure than we do. I don't know why that is. But it is certainly a difficult population group. I know about the Africans from Sudan. They can also work well together with them. However, I must also say that I have mostly worked with Christian-oriented people. And there I also worked with an ophthalmologist who had worked there for a long time. But you always have to stand behind them and always drive them. And I would say, I'm heading for another problem now. We must not pull people out of these Muslim countries, China and African countries. But we have to go into those countries and raise their standard of living. Because they alone are not able to do it. The Chinese can do it. They are raising their standard of living. In the last ten years, as long as I have been there, their standard of living has risen enormously. In China, there is a great economic upswing; in Yemen, that is not the case. And also as I've noted, I've also been to Morocco, tourism is booming there, but they don't have their own industry. Yemen doesn't produce cooking pots, it doesn't produce telephones, it doesn't produce clothing, it doesn't produce anything. It's all imported from China. No industry at all. There are hardly any schools there. 50% are illiterate, in Morocco it is similarly high. And if they go to school and have learned something, there is no education of the students. Vocational training like in our country, nobody learns the profession of a carpenter, or then the next problem is, if they have learned something in English or German or American schools, then they study in Europe and then they stay in Europe and don't go back. That's a very big problem. They have a tremendous loss of their intelligence. Only, just the weak ones stay back there.
speech: [40:37] ich möchte zu Sören etwas sagen. Das Hauptproblem bei allen Immigranten sind die Sprachen. Und zwar ich sehe das immer wieder, da sind die Familien, haben die Türken vier, fünf, sechs Kinder. Die Mutter bleibt zuhause, erzieht ihre Kinder. Die Kinder lernen bis zum sechsten Lebensjahr kein Wort Deutsch. Oder kaum Deutsch. Dann sollen sie in die Schule kommen und versagen in der Schule. Und damit ist die schiefe Ebene gebahnt. Und das ist viel zu spät erkannt worden. Die Kinder müssen im Prinzip mit den deutschen Kindern spielen. Und das wird aber auch von den Türken leider nicht gewollt. Auch mit den Kindergärten. Das reicht nicht aus, wenn beispielsweise in Berlin, da gibt es Gegenden, das sind 50% Türken, 50% Deutsche. Und dann sind die Türken zusammen und die Deutschen zusammen und im Kindergarten lernen die Türken auch nicht  genügend Deutsch. Das ist das Haupthindernis, dass man an die Menschen herankommt und mit ihnen überhaupt eine Diskussion anfängt. Aber da wird inzwischen in Deutschland daran gearbeitet. Aber das ist erst seit einem oder zwei Jahren so und wir hoffen, dass wir damit das Problem in den Griff bekommen. Zur Kriminalität: das ist ein soziologisches Problem. Ein gut ausgebildeter Türke oder Muslim, der ist genau so wenig kriminell wie ein Deutscher. Die Kriminalität ist im Prinzip gleich. Dann wollte ich noch Antonia zu dir etwas sagen. Ich arbeite in China und in arabischen Ländern. Das sind zwei Welten. Die Chinesen sind viel, viel ärmer, die haben wirklich nichts. Da wohnen die Araber noch im Reichtum dagegen. Und ich habe immer wieder Chinesinnen bei uns zuhause, die sind von vornherein, die sind unglaublich strebsam. Die gehen in die Volkshochschule, lernen Deutsch, gehen dann in die Krankenhäuser, weil ich Arzt bin. Ich kann das vermitteln. Bleiben dort ein Jahr, gehen nach China zurück und vermitteln dort ihre Kenntnisse. Mit den Chinesen ist eine ganz hervorragende Kooperation möglich. Wenn man sagt, man fange um 8 an zu arbeiten, dann sind sie um 8 Uhr da. Ich habe es niemals geschafft, in einem Krankenhaus in Jemen zu sagen, ich fange um 8 Uhr an. Der Chef kommt um 11. Und draussen sitzen 30 Patienten, die ich dann mit einer Krankenschwester behandle. Aber wenn sie den Chef bitten und sagen: „tomorrow we start at 8 o’clock, perhaps a quarter past eight“, der kommt nicht vor 10 Uhr. Der hat einfach gar keine Lust. Ich habe festgestellt, es ist ganz ganz schwierig mit denen eine Verabredung zu treffen und dann auch Organisationen durchzuziehen. Die Mentalität der Muslime ist eine völlig andere als der Chinesen und der Europäer. Und die sind auch nicht dümmer, die Muslime oder die Jemeniten. Sie sind nur völlig anders strukturiert als wir. Woran das liegt, weiss ich auch nicht. Aber es ist sicherlich eine schwierige Bevölkerungsgruppe. Mit den Afrikanern weiss ich’s aus dem Sudan. Mit denen können sie auch gut zusammen arbeiten. Ich muss allerdings auch sagen, ich habe da meistens mit christlich orientierten zusammen gearbeitet. Und dort auch mit einer Augenärztin zusammen, die dort lange gearbeitet hat, das geht mit denen. Aber man muss immer dahinter stehen und immer sie treiben. Und ich würde sagen, ich steuere jetzt ein anderes Problem an. Wir dürfen aus diesen muslimischen Ländern, China und den afrikanischen Ländern keine Leute abziehen. Sondern wir müssen in diese Länder gehen und denen den Lebensstandard heben. Denn die alleine sind nicht in der Lage. Die Chinesen können das. Die heben ihren Lebensstandard. Der ist in den letzten zehn Jahren, solange bin ich dort, gewaltig gestiegen. In China ist ein grosser wirtschaftlicher Aufschwung, in Jemen ist das nicht der Fall. Und auch so wie ich es festgestellt habe, ich bin auch in Marokko gewesen, da boomt der Tourismus, aber sie haben keine eigene Industrie. Der Jemen produziert keine Kochtöpfe, kein Telefon, keine Kleidung, kein gar nichts. Das wird alles aus China importiert. Überhaupt keine eigene Industrie. Dort gibt es kaum Schulen. 50% sind Analphabeten, in Marokko ist es ähnlich hoch. Und wenn sie zur Schule gehen und haben etwas gelernt, es gibt keine Ausbildung der Schüler. Berufsausbildung wie bei uns, da lernt keiner den Beruf Schreiner, oder dann ist das nächste Problem, wenn sie auf englischen oder deutschen oder Amerikanischen Schulen etwas gelernt haben, dann studieren sie in Europa und dann bleiben sie in Europa und gehen nicht wieder zurück. Das ist ein ganz grosses Problem. Die haben einen unheimlichen Verlust an ihrer Intelligenz. Es bleiben dort nur, eben die schwachen zurück. [45:52]

Celles qui ne servent à rien, enfin. Nous savons que les passeports, les cartes d’identité qui sont arrivées en touriste, deviennent après illégales parce qu’ils ne sont plus des touristes. And these people were really welcome, but that changed immediately, unfortunately, so when they were more or less integrated, we wanted to send them back to their countries, but of course it didn't work, and in our country there are also very, very different politicians; for example, the politicians that we have now in Austria, for example, have no longer really experienced this phenomenon of refugees from Hungary and so on in their own [lives], so they don't really understand. The new generation has not experienced these dramas anymore so they have a completely different attitude and so this problem is only an Austrian problem but it has to be multiplied by 27 because we obviously have a very very different situation in the different countries of the European Union and even within the countries the situation sometimes changes so it is really not easy to find common solutions. cleaned_comment: I don't think we can say that the policy concerning illegal immigration should be the domain of the country or of the European Union. But afterwards, each country can, in my opinion, harden its position. It is obvious that countries like Spain, Italy, France, which have by tradition or by geographical context, much more immigrants than the countries of Eastern Europe. Well, they don't have the same problems. So there must be a common base and then each country must do what it wants. Terrien? principle of law, which provides well that, a government of a country can authorize or refuse the entry of a foreigner on its country.

cleaned_comment: Yeah, I think as far as immigration is concerned, it's not politically correct to really say what you see. You just can't express your opinion and then it's politically incorrect. For example, I was at another friend's house, there was a street where children used to play, where the older people played chess outside, and now there are no more children. I said, what's going on there? No, you can't sit there anymore. You can't sit there anymore. There are people living there now, they are Moroccans or North Africans, and if you want to sit down there, you have to pay a euro. And you can't go to parks anymore, that's no longer possible. cleaned_comment: On the change actually, the demographic change by the way which are where. Well, it's actually a population incision in Europe, especially in fact a shift towards an older population and less young population. Conversely, in Africa, it is more of a young population or a demographic explosion. In fact, someone from... pragmatically we can think that naturally a transfer of [...] between these two geographical scenes to keep a balance. And clearly, in fact, we can signal the future [...] in Europe. And this need will be felt. I think it will depend on the countries and this is the point in particular of a fashion of how the withdrawals are managed in the different countries. I think that a country like France, where there is a pay-as-you-go system - in fact a transfer from the working population to the retired population - an object is to keep a strong working population to support the retired population, so it's a limit for new workers in countries where a pension that [...] is based on capitalization. This poses a problem. Then there was the simple question of the evolution of economic growth, which is a problem that concerns all countries generally. There is no way to ensure economic growth. We need workers and it is clear that if the European population ages, we will have to find workers elsewhere. So there you have it. Now, demographic protections also vary from country to country. In France, the birth rate is still rising and so it is clear that in countries, especially Germany, this problem would be particularly prevalent and serious.

cleaned_comment: Yes, we have to be careful when we comment, sometimes we interpret things a little bit, but have to be a little bit humble about it I guess. I noticed one thing in particular now for example. Selective immigration of businessmen and employers. Certainly we've seen that at first glance - it's a little bit shocking to me. Why should business leaders be leaders in immigration? Well, focusing on those who have qualification that are scarce to the EU, those should be admitted selectively? I, for example, would say that immigration should be led by employers already, because people who immigrate basically just want a job. If we have a job, we will automatically have an income, if we have an income, then we are just satisfied. After all, that's what we want. Self-reliance. Immigration should then be regulated or controlled, but the whole thing must already be monitored or controlled by the employers as well. Because they will provide the appropriate jobs. That's what I wanted to point out here in particular. But we should not read too much into it here. If we want strongly regulated immigration, that does not mean that we are no longer human. Yes? We can still want this and still be humane about it and still be a little bit altruistic.

Bestimmt haben wir das auf den ersten Blick so erlebt – für mich ist das ein bisschen schockierend. Warum sollten Geschäftsführer federführend sein bei der Einwanderung? Nun, sich fokussiert auf jene, die Qualifikation haben, die der EU knapp sind, die sollten selektiv zugelassen werden? Ich, beispielsweise würde sagen, dass die Einwanderung von den Arbeitgebern schon angeführt werden sollte, weil die Leute, die einwandern im Grunde nur einen Arbeitsplatz wollen. Wenn wir einen Arbeitsplatz haben, werden wir automatisch ein Einkommen haben, wenn  wir ein Einkommen haben, dann sind wir einfach zufrieden. Das ist es ja, was wir wollen. Eigenständigkeit. Die Einwanderung sollte dann reguliert oder kontrolliert werden, aber das Ganze muss schon überwacht oder kontrolliert werden von den Arbeitgebern auch. Denn die werden die entsprechenden Arbeitsstellen anbieten. Das wollte ich im Besonderen aufzeigen hier. Aber wir sollten da nicht allzu viel hineininterpretieren hier. Wenn wir eine stark regulierte Einwanderung wollen, heisst das nicht, dass wir nicht mehr menschlich währen. Ja? cleaned_comment: So, what I could understand when I worked in these two organizations, one of which was rather the reception of immigrants, the other rather in the control of immigration. What I understand is that today the states are still free to set their own rules for their own territory. These rules are more important than the rules set by the EU, which is more concerned with the movement of immigration within the borders. What I could see is that in France, for example, there was a period when people arriving in France were required to sign a contract that included learning the French language. To facilitate integration. Today we have radically changed our approach, that is to say that we ask that people who wish to immigrate to France be able to prove in their own country that they are French. So in fact there are movements of agents of the French state that are in countries that are identified as countries for seeing immigration applications and it is in these countries, when we control for example the language, so that is a first criterion but of course there is another criterion that was posed more recently by the French government which is to identify the professional skills. It's a little bit like the euro question, which effectively means choosing between [...] the immigration population, which is what we need in France today. But there is another phenomenon that is very important, which has been the subject of discussion but which at the same time is laid down as a basic principle by the Geneva Convention. It is the right to family reunification, the fact that a person who has arrived in France has the right to bring his family. So this right is laid down in the Convention on Human Rights. And this is a right that is currently unassailable and that is difficult to reconcile with migration policies in the framework that states would like to make of this migration policy. Here is the reading of what I could see and understand.
speech: [33 :25] Donc, ce que j’ai pu en comprendre quand j’ai travaillé dans ces deux organismes, dont l’un était plutôt l’accueil des immigrés, l’autre plutôt dans le control de l’immigration. Ce que je comprends c’est qu’aujourd’hui les états restent assez mettre de poser leurs propres règles sur par rapport à leur propre territoire. Ça reste des règles prépondérantes par rapport aux règles qui sont posés par l’UE, qu’elle chère plus des mouvements de l’immigration à l’intérieur des frontières. Ce que je pu en voir, c'est qu’on a eu par exemple en France la période ou on a posé à ce que les personnes qui arrivent en France signent un contrat qui prévoyait notamment d’apprendre la langue française. Pour pouvoir faciliter l’intégration. Aujourd’hui on a changé radicalement de tique, c'est-à-dire qu’en fait on demande a ce que les personnes qui souhaitent immigrer en France, soit déjà en mesure de prouver dans leur pays qu’elle sasse par les français. Donc en fait il y a des déplacements d’agents de l’état français qui ont êtes dans les pays qui sont identifiés comme des pays pour voyer demande d’immigration et c’est dans ces pays la, quand qu’on contrôle par exemple la langue, alors ça c'est un premier critère mais bien sur y a un autre critère que était posé plus récemment par le gouvernement français qui est d’identifier les compétences professionnels. Ça reprend un petit peu la question d’euro qui effectivement, de choisir entre […] la population d’immigration donc on a besoin aujourd’hui en France ça. Mais y a un autre phénomène qu’est très important, qui a été sujet à discussion mais qui en même temps est posé comme principe de base par la convention de Genève. C’est le droit regroupement familial, le fait qu’une personne quand elle est arrivée en France, elle a le droit de faire venir sa famille. Donc ce droit-là, il est posé au titre de la convention du droit de l’homme. Et ça c’est un droit pour l’instant inattaquable et qui se concilie difficilement avec les politiques de migration dans l’encadrement que voudraient faire les états de cette politique de migration. Voila, moi la lecture de ce que j’ai pu en voir et en comprendre. [35 :57]
